title: Your unofficial guide to creating Player Support requests!
body:
http://i.imgur.com/cEXyHYg.jpg

When [**submitting a request to Riot Games Player Support**](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/requests/new), there are some tips and tricks that will make the request process a lot smoother for both you and Player Support. As such, it might be useful to go over some of the best ways to communicate with Support. Here are the top do's and don'ts for submitting a ticket:
______________
>#Don't:

* **DO NOT** threaten player support, whether legal, physical, etc. Once you've indicated that you're looking for a legal solution to your problem, you'll likely be redirected to the Terms of Use's legal section; in this case, Player Support won't be able to assist you any further. 

* **DO NOT** create multiple tickets. Player Support will try to reference information in past tickets as well, and most likely respond to the most recently opened ticket. This means that new tickets will effectively bump your tickets to the end of the queue, delaying a response. 

* **DO NOT** bump your ticket/reply to your ticket before Player Support has the opportunity to respond. This will bump your ticket to the end of the queue, delaying a response. 

>#Do:

* **DO** if possible, create one ticket per account. It's easier to manage requests this way. 

* **DO** treat Player Support with respect. Cussing won't make the process go any faster.

* **DO** read the appropriate Knowledge Base article before sending a ticket. This will allow you to provide as much relevant information as possible so Support doesn't have to follow-up asking you for more information. 
______________________

>#And lastly: 

* **If you're unsure where to put your ticket in, just select:**
[*I have a question about League of Legends/Riot Games.*] > [*Game and Features*] > [*General Questions*]

Requests like Player Behavior requests, event questions, etc. would be fine in this category. 

* If you're unable to submit a ticket through the Support Portal, send your request via support@riotgames.com. It may take a bit longer, but it'll get the job done as well. 

* If you're submitting a tech ticket, please attach the logs generated with the [**Hextech Repair Tool**](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/224826367).
_______________________

If you have any questions or have any tips that you'd like to add, drop a comment below!
_______________________

> These are some other tips that apply to requesting technical support in general from anyone. They are mostly geared to software/system issues, but you get the idea.
> 
> 1. **Provide information as concisely as possible** – Support people spend all day reading tickets and it’s tough to read through a couple of paragraphs to get something that could be said in a line or two. Formatting the ticket in sections and bullet points makes it easier to read than a solid block of 1,000 words.
> 2. **Provide the most information you can that closely relates to the problem** – This is information that you know they’ll probably need to know and will ask of you. Instead of waiting for another round of messages exchanged, provide details on the initial ticket: error messages, screenshots, how to re-create the problem, what you have tried to resolve the issue and the results, changes in your system before problem appeared
> 3. **Some sections to include** - Thankfully, Riot’s ticket submission form specifically asks for some of this information, but these are: 
> 
> 
> 
> * **Subject** - Use a few keywords describing the situation without necessitating a long phrase. The subject information will assist the Support Team in understanding at a glance what is the nature of the request. Avoid generic phrases such as "Help Needed" or "Urgent Assistance Required". An example "Client crashes with message "PVP.net Patcher Kernel has stopped working". An accurate subject line may help a support tech to quickly identify the problem/cause/solution because he may have seen it many times before. 
> * **Description **- Here is where to include the detailed information regarding the request. Include the following information but not limited to
> * **Issue **– Brief re-statement of the problem
> * **Error Message(s)** – may pinpoint the problem, cause and solution to the agent
> * **Steps to reproduce** – What you do, what happens just before the problem occurs, changes made to system prior to problem ( updated OS, re-installed LoL)
> * **Attachments **– screen shots may show error messages or things on screen that may be difficult or take long to described, log files with possible error messages
> * **Steps you have taken to attempt to solve problem** – this may save time since support agent may have been planning to tell you to try just that (like re-installing), it gives an idea of how well you understand the problem, the attempted solution needs to be taken into consideration for the solution (changes original conditions or made the problem worse)
> 
>  The more information there is, the better the support agent will be able to assist you with the request.

These are some other tips that apply to requesting technical support in general from anyone. They are mostly geared to software/system issues, but you get the idea.

1. **Provide information as concisely as possible** – Support people spend all day reading tickets and it’s tough to read through a couple of paragraphs to get something that could be said in a line or two. Formatting the ticket in sections and bullet points makes it easier to read than a solid block of 1,000 words.
2. **Provide the most information you can that closely relates to the problem** – This is information that you know they’ll probably need to know and will ask of you. Instead of waiting for another round of messages exchanged, provide details on the initial ticket: error messages, screenshots, how to re-create the problem, what you have tried to resolve the issue and the results, changes in your system before problem appeared
3. **Some sections to include** - Thankfully, Riot’s ticket submission form specifically asks for some of this information, but these are: 



* **Subject** - Use a few keywords describing the situation without necessitating a long phrase. The subject information will assist the Support Team in understanding at a glance what is the nature of the request. Avoid generic phrases such as "Help Needed" or "Urgent Assistance Required". An example "Client crashes with message "PVP.net Patcher Kernel has stopped working". An accurate subject line may help a support tech to quickly identify the problem/cause/solution because he may have seen it many times before. 
* **Description **- Here is where to include the detailed information regarding the request. Include the following information but not limited to
* **Issue **– Brief re-statement of the problem
* **Error Message(s)** – may pinpoint the problem, cause and solution to the agent
* **Steps to reproduce** – What you do, what happens just before the problem occurs, changes made to system prior to problem ( updated OS, re-installed LoL)
* **Attachments **– screen shots may show error messages or things on screen that may be difficult or take long to described, log files with possible error messages
* **Steps you have taken to attempt to solve problem** – this may save time since support agent may have been planning to tell you to try just that (like re-installing), it gives an idea of how well you understand the problem, the attempted solution needs to be taken into consideration for the solution (changes original conditions or made the problem worse)

 The more information there is, the better the support agent will be able to assist you with the request.

Ah, when I said bumping, I meant replying before support replied. If you don't believe your request/question was answered completely, you're more than free to clarify your question or inform them that parts of your request remain unanswered :)

It's always a terribly inadequate automated response, and sometimes a response that has literally nothing to do with the issue at hand. Back when Riot updated the client and the patcher interface (end of season 4 I believe), mine never updated. I told riot in a support ticket that "my patcher didn't update properly/at all" and they responded with a link to the FAQ page on patching errors. I had to bump that at least twice to finally get answers, and that is not ok.

A few days after the ticket is closed, you're sent an email asking for feedback on your experience with the ticket. If you're feeling that it takes 2-3 tickets before your request is directly addressed, you should provide that feedback in that survey. I assure you that those surveys are reviewed, both as aggregate statistics and as individual feedback.

Deep Terror Nami did make a comment that was not reflective of the program and was not necessarily appropriate in the context that it was mentioned. Arbiters are free to have their own opinions and discuss them openly; however, the way the message is conveyed is important in ensuring that people understand that these statements are representative only of an individual's opinions and that they're at least fair statements. 

An example of this would be, "The balance team is absolute garbage at their job" vs. "I don't believe that the balance team has created a conducive environment over the past season" (note that this isn't necessarily my belief regarding the state of the game. It's just an example of variation in messaging). 

Additionally, Support is trained to respond to your requests efficiently, and from what I can tell, that may mean utilizing a pre-formatted response. It's not in Riot's best interest to lie to its customers, from what I would imagine.
